case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 1737 to 1745 of 1972 and Civil Appeals Nos. 1870 and 1871 of 1972

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1737 to 1745 of 1972 were filed from the Judgment and order dated the 9th December 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos.661, 662, 665, 666, 668, 681, 682, 684 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1737 to 1745 of 1972. From the Judgment and order dated the 9th December 1971 of the Allahabad High Court at Allahabad in Special Appeals Nos.661 662, 665, 666, 668, 681, 682, 684 of 1968.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1870 and 1871 of 1972 were filed from the Judgment and Order dated the 9th December, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 675 and 676 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: And Civil Appeals Nos. 1870 1871 of 1972 From the Judgment and Order dated the 9th December, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court at Allahabad in Special Appeals Nos. 675 and 676 of 1968. Sen, D. N. Misra, J. B. Dadachanji, O.C Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellants  in C. A. Nos. 1737 to 1745  D. Sharma, for the appellant  in C. A. No. 1870-71  Niren De, Attorney General of India, and O. P. Rana, for the respondents.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KHANNA, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KHANNA, J.-The validity of schemes approved by the Uttar Pradesh Government under section 68D of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939  Act 4 of 1939   hereinafter referred to as the Act  for inter-State routes as a result of which private operators including those who had been granted permits by Regional Transport Authorities of Rajasthan were excluded from those routes has been called in question in civil appeals No. 1737-1745 of 1972 and civil appeals No. 1870 and 1871 of 1972 which have been filed on certificate against the companymon judgment of the Allahabad High Court.

facts.text: Counsel for the parties agreed that the decision in civil appeal No. 1738 would govern the other appeals as the question of law is identical.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment would dispose of all the appeals. It would be necessary to reproduce only the facts of the case giving rise to civil appeal No. 1738, for the companynsel for the parties are agreed that the decision in that appeal would also govern the other appeals as the question of law involved in all these appeals is identical.

facts.text: On June 14, 1960 a letter was sent by the Deputy Secretary to the Government of Rajasthan to the Secretary to the Government of Uttar Pradesh approving nationalisation of routes Bharatpur-Agra, Bharatpur-Mathura, Alwar-Mathura, Mathura-Kama Kosi via Goverdhan, Agra-Dholpur.

anchor.surface_text: On June 14, 1960 a letter was sent by the Deputy Secretary to the Government of Rajasthan to the Secretary to the Government of Uttar Pradesh in reply to an earlier letter received from the Transport Commission Uttar Pradesh companyveying approval of the Rajasthan Government for the nationalisation of the undermentioned routes for the operation of services by the State transport undertakings of both States in accordance with the reciprocal arrangement arrived at between the two States Bharatpur-Agra Bharatpur-Mathura Alwar-Mathura Mathura-Kama Kosi via Goverdhan Agra-Dholpur

facts.text: The present appeals are concerned with four routes: Bharatpur-Agra, Alwar-Mathura, Mathura-Kama Kosi via Goverdhan, Agra-Dholpur (excluding Bharatpur-Mathura).

anchor.surface_text: We are in the present appeals companycerned with four of the routes, i.e. the routes mentioned above other than Bharatpur-Mathura route. Appeal No. 1738 of 1972 relates to Dholpur-Agra route.

facts.text: Appeal No. 1738 of 1972 relates to Dholpur-Agra route.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 1738 of 1972 relates to Dholpur-Agra route. It may be mentioned that Dholpur, Bharatpur, Alwar and Kama Kosi are situated in Rajasthan, while Agra and Mathura are situated in Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Dholpur, Bharatpur, Alwar and Kama Kosi are situated in Rajasthan, while Agra and Mathura are situated in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that Dholpur, Bharatpur, Alwar and Kama Kosi are situated in Rajasthan, while Agra and Mathura are situated in Uttar Pradesh. Notification dated December 4, 1961 was published in the P. Gazette dated December 9, 1961 by the Uttar Pradesh Government under section 68C of the Act in respect of proposed scheme for providing State road transport passenger services on inter-State Agra-Dholpur route.

facts.text: Notification dated December 4, 1961 published in U.P. Gazette dated December 9, 1961 by Uttar Pradesh Government under section 68C for proposed scheme on Agra-Dholpur route.

anchor.surface_text: Notification dated December 4, 1961 was published in the P. Gazette dated December 9, 1961 by the Uttar Pradesh Government under section 68C of the Act in respect of proposed scheme for providing State road transport passenger services on inter-State Agra-Dholpur route. According to the propose scheme, numberpersons other than the State transport undertaking would be permitted to provide any road transport services on the route or portions thereof.

facts.text: The proposed scheme excluded persons other than the State transport undertaking from providing road transport services on Agra-Dholpur route or portions thereof and envisaged cancellation of permits to private operators including appellants.

anchor.surface_text: According to the propose scheme, numberpersons other than the State transport undertaking would be permitted to provide any road transport services on the route or portions thereof. The scheme also visualised the cancellation of the permits which had been granted to the private operators, including the appellants.

facts.text: No objections were filed against the proposed scheme for Agra-Dholpur route.

anchor.surface_text: Objections were invited with regard to the proposed Scheme from persons affected by the scheme. No objections were, however, filed against the aforesaid scheme and the same was approved under section 68D 2  of the Act by the Joint Judicial Secretary to the Government of Uttar Pradesh, who was the hearing authority, as per order dated July 30, 1962.

facts.text: The scheme was approved under section 68D(2) by the Joint Judicial Secretary to the Government of Uttar Pradesh on July 30, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: No objections were, however, filed against the aforesaid scheme and the same was approved under section 68D 2  of the Act by the Joint Judicial Secretary to the Government of Uttar Pradesh, who was the hearing authority, as per order dated July 30, 1962. The Central Government companyveyed its approval to the scheme under the proviso to sub-section  3  of section 68D of the Act as per letter dated February 6, 1963.

facts.text: Central Government conveyed approval to the scheme under proviso to s68D(3) on February 6, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government companyveyed its approval to the scheme under the proviso to sub-section  3  of section 68D of the Act as per letter dated February 6, 1963. Notification dated February 20, 1963 was published by the Uttar Pradesh Government in the official Gazette dated March 16, 1963 for the publication of the approved scheme under sub-section  3  of section 68D of the Act.

facts.text: Notification dated February 20, 1963 published in official Gazette March 16, 1963 for approved scheme under s68D(3).

anchor.surface_text: Notification dated February 20, 1963 was published by the Uttar Pradesh Government in the official Gazette dated March 16, 1963 for the publication of the approved scheme under sub-section  3  of section 68D of the Act. Clauses 1, 2, 4 and 8 of the scheme read as under The State Road Transport passenger services shall companymence to operate from April 1, 1963 or thereafter.

facts.text: State Road Transport passenger services to commence from April 1, 1963 or thereafter on Agra-Dholpur route.

anchor.surface_text: Clauses 1, 2, 4 and 8 of the scheme read as under The State Road Transport passenger services shall companymence to operate from April 1, 1963 or thereafter. State Road Transport passenger services shall be provided on the Inter-State route Agra Dholpur of Agra Region. No persons other than the State Transport Undertakings will be permitted to provide any Road Transport Services on this route or portions thereof specified in Clause  2  above.

facts.text: The approved scheme provided that no persons other than State Transport Undertakings permitted on the route and private vehicles reduced to nil; permits of private operators cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: State Road Transport passenger services shall be provided on the Inter-State route Agra Dholpur of Agra Region. No persons other than the State Transport Undertakings will be permitted to provide any Road Transport Services on this route or portions thereof specified in Clause  2  above. The number of private Transport Vehicles on the route or portion thereof specified in clause  2  above shall be reduced to nil.

facts.text: By notification dated April 9, 1963, permits of private operators including appellants issued by RTA Jaipur and countersigned by RTA Agra were cancelled under s68F(2).

anchor.surface_text: By numberification dated April 9, 1963 the permits in favour of the private operators, including the appellants, issued by the Regional Transport Authority, Jaipur and companyntersigned by the Regional Transport Authority, Agra were cancelled under sub-section  2  of section 68F of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants, bus operators of Rajasthan, filed petitions under Articles 226 and 227 challenging the notifications.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, who are bus operators of Rajasthan, and some others thereupon filed petitions under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution to challenge the validity of the above numberifications.

facts.text: Learned single Judge quashed the impugned notifications holding unilateral action invalid and ineffective notice.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge who heard the writ petitions came to the companyclusion that a State companyld number by taking unilateral action provide transport services for a territory outside the limits of its own territory. ... Finding was also given that effective numberice had number been given to the bus operators of. Rajasthan as the numberifications were published in the Gazette of Uttar Pradesh only. The writ petitions were accordingly allowed and the impugned numberifications were quashed by the learned single Judge.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court allowed appeals by State, held schemes and notifications valid.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Division Bench of the High Court held that when an undertaking proposes a scheme and the same is approved by the State Government, the undertaking and the State Government really perform the functions of the Central Government under clause  2  of article 258 of the Constitution. ... The Division Bench accordingly allowed the appeals filed by the State and held that the impugned schemes and numberifications Were valid in law.

facts.text: High Court repelled contention that appellants had no knowledge of schemes, holding notices were published properly and put on notice boards of transport authorities of both states.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the companytention advanced on behalf of the appellants that they had numberknowledge of the proposed schemes. It was observed that the. relevant provisions for publication of the schemes were companyplied with and that numberices were put up on the numberice boards of the State transport authorities of Uttar Pradesh as well as of Rajas- than.

facts.text: Central Government approval obtained on February 6, 1963 for the inter-State route.

anchor.surface_text: Such previous approval of the Central Government was admittedly obtained in respect of the inter- State route with which we are companycerned, as per letter dated February 19, 1963.

facts.text: Agra-Dholpur is an inter-State route as termini are in two different States.

anchor.surface_text: An inter-State route is one of which one of the termini falls in one State and the other in another State. Agra-Dholpur route is admitted an inter- State route as the termini of the route are situated in two different States.

issues.text: Whether the schemes approved by the Uttar Pradesh Government under section 68D of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 for inter-State routes, excluding private operators granted permits by Rajasthan authorities, are valid?

anchor.surface_text: The validity of schemes approved by the Uttar Pradesh Government under section 68D of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939  Act 4 of 1939   hereinafter referred to as the Act  for inter-State routes as a result of which private operators including those who had been granted permits by Regional Transport Authorities of Rajasthan were excluded from those routes has been called in question in civil appeals No. 1737-1745 of 1972 and civil appeals No. 1870 and 1871 of 1972 which have been filed on certificate against the companymon judgment of the Allahabad High Court.

issues.text: Whether a State Government can approve a scheme for an inter-State route under section 68D of the Act, given territorial limits on its powers?

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on behalf of the appellants that a State Government cannot approve a scheme for inter-State route under section 68D of the Act as the powers of the State Government can operate within its own territory and cannot operate in an area beyond the territorial limits of the State.

issues.text: Whether the approval of the State Government for a scheme relating to an inter-State route can only be in respect of the portion within its own territory and not the entire route?
Whether approving a scheme under section 68D constitutes law-making by the State Government, rendering it unconstitutional for inter-State routes beyond territorial limits?
Whether the State Government in approving a scheme exercises executive power that cannot operate beyond its territorial limits?
Whether the schemes and notifications are valid regarding notice to operators and cancellation of permits?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the contention advanced on behalf of the appellants that they had no knowledge of the proposed schemes. It was observed that the relevant provisions for publication of the schemes were complied with and that notices were put up on the notice boards of the State transport authorities of Uttar Pradesh as well as of Rajasthan.

issues.text: Whether the validity of the action can be sustained under clause (2) of article 258 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge who heard the writ petitions came to the conclusion that a State could not by taking unilateral action provide transport services for a territory outside the limits of its own territory.

arguments.court_reasoning: No necessity for Central approval if only intra-state portion; inter-state requires Central approval for entire route

arguments.court_reasoning: Statutory power under Parliamentary law (Chapter IVA); Art298 executive power for trade/business without territorial limits, subject to Parliament (entries 21,35 List III)

arguments.claim: Schemes approved under s68D for inter-State routes excluding private operators are valid as proviso to s68D(3) empowers State Government with Central approval

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, cannot be accepted as it runs counter to the plain language of the proviso to sub-section (3) of section 68D of the Act. According to the proviso, no scheme which relates to an inter-State route shall be deemed to be an approved scheme unless it has been published in the Official Gazette with the previous approval of the Central Government.

arguments.claim: Chapter IVA validly enacted by Parliament under entries 21 and 35 List III; enables State monopoly in transport

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the question of State monopoly in the matter of transport service as envisaged by Chapter IVA of the Act, Shah J. speaking for the Court observed in the above mentioned case... We are therefore of the view that Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List.

arguments.claim: Validity of UP Government approval not to be decided under Art 258(2)
Proviso to s68D(3) construction does not contravene Constitution

holdings.text: A State Government is competent to approve a scheme relating to an inter-State route under section 68D of the Motor Vehicles Act with the previous approval of the Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, cannot be accepted as it runs counter to the plain language of the proviso to sub-section (3) of section 68D of the Act. According to the proviso, no scheme which relates to an inter-State route shall be deemed to be an approved scheme unless it has been published in the Official Gazette with the previous approval of the Central Government. The proviso manifestly contemplates that the State Government can in accordance with the procedure laid down in Chapter IVA of the Act approve a scheme relating to an inter-State route and publish the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of proviso to s68D(3) expressly contemplates State approval for inter-State routes subject only to prior Central Government approval, which was obtained.

holdings.text: The Uttar Pradesh Government was competent to approve and publish the impugned scheme relating to Agra-Dholpur inter-State route.

anchor.surface_text: In the face of the proviso to sub-section (3) of section 68D of the Act, we find it difficult to accede to the submission that the Uttar Pradesh Government was not competent to approve and publish the impugned scheme relating to Agra-Dholpur route.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s68D(3) and admitted prior Central approval under letter dated February 6, 1963.

holdings.text: Approval of the State Government for a scheme relating to an inter-State route is in respect of the entire inter-State route and not only the portion within its territory.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessity for Central approval arises only for entire inter-State route; no need if only intra-State portion.

holdings.text: When a State Government approves a scheme under s68D, it does not make law in the sense of legislation under Article 245.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme approval is executive/statutory action under Parliamentary law, not legislative power of State Legislature; Art13(3) definition limited to fundamental rights context.

holdings.text: State Government approval of inter-State scheme under s68D exercises statutory power conferred by Parliament, not limited by territorial executive power.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter IVA enacted by Parliament under Entries 21 & 35 List III; Art298 executive power for trade/business without territorial limits, subject to Parliamentary law.

holdings.text: Chapter IVA of the Motor Vehicles Act could competently be enacted by Parliament under Entry 21 read with Entry 35 of the Concurrent List.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in H.C. Narayanappa v. State of Mysore; empowers State monopolies in road transport.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether the UP Government's approval can be sustained under Article 258(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Schemes valid under MV Act s68D; alternative ground unnecessary.

holdings.text: The construction placed on proviso to s68D(3) entails no contravention of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious with constitutional provisions on legislative competence, executive power, and federalism.

precedents.citation: H.C. Narayanappa and Ors. v. The State of Mysore and Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: H.C. Narayanappa and Ors. v. The State of Mysore and Ors.  1  is wide enough to include grant or creation of companymercial or industrial monopolies to the State and citizens as well as companytrol of monopolies. , Dealing with the question of State monopoly in the matter of transport service as envisaged by Chapter IVA of the Act, Shah J. speaking for the Court observed in the above mentioned case The amplitude of the powers under the entry in the companycurrent list expressly dealing with companymercial and industrial monopolies cannot be presumed to be restricted by the generality of the expression trade and companymerce in the State list.

precedents.case_name: H.C. Narayanappa v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: The expression 'commercical and industrial monopolies' is wide enough to include grant or creation of commercial or industrial monopolies to the State and citizens as well as control of monopolies; Parliament can competently enact Chapter IVA under entry 21 read with entry 35 of Concurrent List
precedents.cited_holding: The amplitude of the powers under the entry in the concurrent list expressly dealing with commercial and industrial monopolies cannot be presumed to be restricted by the generality of the expression trade and commerce in the State list. ... Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List.

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji and Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji and Ors.  1  related to the validity of Rule 26 of the Defence of India Rules framed under the Defence of India Act, 1939. The Rule was held to be valid. It was also held that it was number necessary for the Governor to be personally satisfied before an order under the above Rule companyld be made. Dealing with the term executive, the Judicial Committee held that it includes both a decision as to action and the carrying out of such a decision.

precedents.cited_proposition: Definition of 'executive' includes both a decision as to action and the carrying out of such a decision; disagreement with narrow reading of sections 49(2) and 124(2) of the Government of India Act, 1935

outcome.relief_summary: Validity of nationalisation schemes under section 68D for inter-State routes upheld; UP Government competent to approve; permits of private operators validly cancelled; no encroachment on Rajasthan's executive power

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, cannot be accepted as it runs counter to the plain language of the proviso to sub-section (3) of section 68D of the Act. According to the proviso, no scheme which relates to an inter-State route shall be deemed to be an approved scheme unless it has been published in the Official Gazette with the previous approval of the Central Government. The proviso manifestly contemplates that the State Government can in accordance with the procedure laid down in Chapter IVA of the Act approve a scheme relating to an inter-State route and publish the same.

The proviso manifestly contemplates that the State Government can in accordance with the procedure laid down in Chapter IVA of the Act approve a scheme relating to an inter-State route and publish the same.
